args.description: (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the resource.

attrs.name: id
attrs.description: The db subnet group name.

attrs.name: arn
attrs.description: The ARN of the db subnet group.

args.name: cluster_identifier
args.description: (Optional, Forces new resources) The cluster identifier. If omitted, Terraform will assign a random, unique identifier.

args.name: cluster_identifier_prefix
args.description: (Optional, Forces new resource) Creates a unique cluster identifier beginning with the specified prefix. Conflicts with cluster_identifier.

args.name: database_name
args.description: (Optional) Name for an automatically created database on cluster creation. There are different naming restrictions per database engine: RDS Naming Constraints

args.name: deletion_protection
args.description: (Optional) If the DB instance should have deletion protection enabled. The database can't be deleted when this value is set to true. The default is false.

args.name: master_password
args.description:
(Required unless a snapshot_identifier is provided) Password for the master DB user. Note that this may
  show up in logs, and it will be stored in the state file. Please refer to the RDS Naming Constraints

args.name: master_username
args.description: (Required unless a snapshot_identifier is provided) Username for the master DB user. Please refer to the RDS Naming Constraints

args.name: final_snapshot_identifier
args.description:
(Optional) The name of your final DB snapshot
  when this DB cluster is deleted. If omitted, no final snapshot will be
  made.

args.name: skip_final_snapshot
args.description: (Optional) Determines whether a final DB snapshot is created before the DB cluster is deleted. If true is specified, no DB snapshot is created. If false is specified, a DB snapshot is created before the DB cluster is deleted, using the value from final_snapshot_identifier. Default is false.

args.name: availability_zones
args.description:
(Optional) A list of EC2 Availability Zones that
instances in the DB cluster can be created in

args.name: backtrack_window
args.description: (Optional) The target backtrack window, in seconds. Only available for aurora engine currently. To disable backtracking, set this value to 0. Defaults to 0. Must be between 0 and 259200 (72 hours)

args.name: backup_retention_period
args.description: (Optional) The days to retain backups for. Default 1

args.name: preferred_backup_window
args.description:
(Optional) The daily time range during which automated backups are created if automated backups are enabled using the BackupRetentionPeriod parameter.Time in UTC
Default: A 30-minute window selected at random from an 8-hour block of time per region. e.g. 04:00-09:00

args.name: preferred_maintenance_window
args.description: (Optional) The weekly time range during which system maintenance can occur, in (UTC) e.g. wed:04:00-wed:04:30

args.name: port
args.description: (Optional) The port on which the DB accepts connections

args.name: bucket_name
args.description: (Required) The bucket name where your backup is stored

args.name: bucket_prefix
args.description: (Optional) Can be blank, but is the path to your backup

args.name: ingestion_role
args.description: (Required) Role applied to load the data.

args.name: source_engine
args.description: (Required) Source engine for the backup

args.name: source_engine_version
args.description: (Required) Version of the source engine used to make the backup

args.name: vpc_security_group_ids
args.description:
(Optional) List of VPC security groups to associate
with the Cluster

args.name: snapshot_identifier
args.description: (Optional) Specifies whether or not to create this cluster from a snapshot. You can use either the name or ARN when specifying a DB cluster snapshot, or the ARN when specifying a DB snapshot.

args.name: storage_encrypted
args.description: (Optional) Specifies whether the DB cluster is encrypted. The default is false for provisioned engine_mode and true for serverless engine_mode.

args.name: replication_source_identifier
args.description: (Optional) ARN of a source DB cluster or DB instance if this DB cluster is to be created as a Read Replica.

args.name: apply_immediately
args.description:
(Optional) Specifies whether any cluster modifications
   are applied immediately, or during the next maintenance window. Default is
   false. See Amazon RDS Documentation for more information.

args.name: db_subnet_group_name
args.description: (Optional) A DB subnet group to associate with this DB instance. NOTE: This must match the db_subnet_group_name specified on every aws_rds_cluster_instance in the cluster.

args.name: db_cluster_parameter_group_name
args.description: (Optional) A cluster parameter group to associate with the cluster.

args.name: kms_key_id
args.description: (Optional) The ARN for the KMS encryption key. When specifying kms_key_id, storage_encrypted needs to be set to true.

args.name: iam_roles
args.description: (Optional) A List of ARNs for the IAM roles to associate to the RDS Cluster.

args.name: iam_database_authentication_enabled
args.description: (Optional) Specifies whether or mappings of AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) accounts to database accounts is enabled. Please see AWS Documentation for availability and limitations.

args.name: engine
args.description: (Optional) The name of the database engine to be used for this DB cluster. Defaults to aurora. Valid Values: aurora, aurora-mysql, aurora-postgresql

args.name: auto_pause
args.description: (Optional) Whether to enable automatic pause. A DB cluster can be paused only when it's idle (it has no connections). If a DB cluster is paused for more than seven days, the DB cluster might be backed up with a snapshot. In this case, the DB cluster is restored when there is a request to connect to it. Defaults to true.

args.name: max_capacity
args.description: (Optional) The maximum capacity. The maximum capacity must be greater than or equal to the minimum capacity. Valid capacity values are 2, 4, 8, 16, 32, 64, 128, and 256. Defaults to 16.

args.name: min_capacity
args.description: (Optional) The minimum capacity. The minimum capacity must be lesser than or equal to the maximum capacity. Valid capacity values are 2, 4, 8, 16, 32, 64, 128, and 256. Defaults to 2.

args.name: seconds_until_auto_pause
args.description: (Optional) The time, in seconds, before an Aurora DB cluster in serverless mode is paused. Valid values are 300 through 86400. Defaults to 300.

args.name: engine_mode
args.description: (Optional) The database engine mode. Valid values: global, parallelquery, provisioned, serverless. Defaults to: provisioned. See the RDS User Guide for limitations when using serverless.

args.name: engine_version
args.description: (Optional) The database engine version. Updating this argument results in an outage.

args.name: source_region
args.description: (Optional) The source region for an encrypted replica DB cluster.

args.name: enabled_cloudwatch_logs_exports
args.description:
(Optional) List of log types to export to cloudwatch. If omitted, no logs will be exported.
 The following log types are supported: audit, error, general, slowquery.

args.name: scaling_configuration
args.description: (Optional) Nested attribute with scaling properties. Only valid when engine_mode is set to serverless. More details below.

args.name: tags
args.description: (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the DB cluster.

args.name: monitoring_role_arn
args.description:
(Optional) The ARN for the IAM role that permits RDS to send
enhanced monitoring metrics to CloudWatch Logs. You can find more information on the AWS Documentation
what IAM permissions are needed to allow Enhanced Monitoring for RDS Instances.

args.name: monitoring_interval
args.description: (Optional) The interval, in seconds, between points when Enhanced Monitoring metrics are collected for the DB instance. To disable collecting Enhanced Monitoring metrics, specify 0. The default is 0. Valid Values: 0, 1, 5, 10, 15, 30, 60.

args.name: promotion_tier
args.description: (Optional) Default 0. Failover Priority setting on instance level. The reader who has lower tier has higher priority to get promoter to writer.

args.name: availability_zone
args.description: (Optional, Computed) The EC2 Availability Zone that the DB instance is created in. See docs about the details.

args.name: preferred_backup_window
args.description:
(Optional) The daily time range during which automated backups are created if automated backups are enabled.
Eg: "04:00-09:00"

args.name: preferred_maintenance_window
args.description:
(Optional) The window to perform maintenance in.
Syntax: "ddd:hh24:mi-ddd:hh24:mi". Eg: "Mon:00:00-Mon:03:00".

args.name: auto_minor_version_upgrade
args.description: (Optional) Indicates that minor engine upgrades will be applied automatically to the DB instance during the maintenance window. Default true.

args.name: performance_insights_enabled
args.description: (Optional) Specifies whether Performance Insights is enabled or not.

args.name: performance_insights_kms_key_id
args.description: (Optional) The ARN for the KMS key to encrypt Performance Insights data. When specifying performance_insights_kms_key_id, performance_insights_enabled needs to be set to true.

args.name: copy_tags_to_snapshot
args.description: – (Optional, boolean) Indicates whether to copy all of the userdefined tags from the DB instance to snapshots of the DB instance. Default false.

args.name: tags
args.description: (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the instance.

  engines can't apply some parameters without a reboot, and you will need to
  specify "pending-reboot" here.

args.name: apply_immediately
args.description: (Optional) Specifies whether any cluster modifications are applied immediately, or during the next maintenance window. Default is false.

args.name: availability_zones
args.description: (Optional) A list of EC2 Availability Zones that instances in the Neptune cluster can be created in.

args.name: backup_retention_period
args.description: (Optional) The days to retain backups for. Default 1

args.name: cluster_identifier
args.description: (Optional, Forces new resources) The cluster identifier. If omitted, Terraform will assign a random, unique identifier.

args.name: cluster_identifier_prefix
args.description: (Optional, Forces new resource) Creates a unique cluster identifier beginning with the specified prefix. Conflicts with cluster_identifier.

args.name: engine
args.description: (Optional) The name of the database engine to be used for this Neptune cluster. Defaults to neptune.

args.name: engine_version
args.description: (Optional) The database engine version.

args.name: final_snapshot_identifier
args.description: (Optional) The name of your final Neptune snapshot when this Neptune cluster is deleted. If omitted, no final snapshot will be made.

args.name: iam_roles
args.description: (Optional) A List of ARNs for the IAM roles to associate to the Neptune Cluster.

args.name: iam_database_authentication_enabled
args.description: (Optional) Specifies whether or mappings of AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) accounts to database accounts is enabled.

args.name: kms_key_arn
args.description: (Optional) The ARN for the KMS encryption key. When specifying kms_key_arn, storage_encrypted needs to be set to true.

args.name: neptune_subnet_group_name
args.description: (Optional) A Neptune subnet group to associate with this Neptune instance.

args.name: neptune_cluster_parameter_group_name
args.description: (Optional) A cluster parameter group to associate with the cluster.

args.name: preferred_backup_window
args.description: (Optional) The daily time range during which automated backups are created if automated backups are enabled using the BackupRetentionPeriod parameter. Time in UTC. Default: A 30-minute window selected at random from an 8-hour block of time per region. e.g. 04:00-09:00

args.name: preferred_maintenance_window
args.description: (Optional) The weekly time range during which system maintenance can occur, in (UTC) e.g. wed:04:00-wed:04:30

args.name: port
args.description: (Optional) The port on which the Neptune accepts connections. Default is 8182.

args.name: replication_source_identifier
args.description: (Optional) ARN of a source Neptune cluster or Neptune instance if this Neptune cluster is to be created as a Read Replica.

args.name: skip_final_snapshot
args.description: (Optional) Determines whether a final Neptune snapshot is created before the Neptune cluster is deleted. If true is specified, no Neptune snapshot is created. If false is specified, a Neptune snapshot is created before the Neptune cluster is deleted, using the value from final_snapshot_identifier. Default is false.

args.name: snapshot_identifier
args.description: (Optional) Specifies whether or not to create this cluster from a snapshot. You can use either the name or ARN when specifying a Neptune cluster snapshot, or the ARN when specifying a Neptune snapshot.

args.name: storage_encrypted
args.description: (Optional) Specifies whether the Neptune cluster is encrypted. The default is false if not specified.

args.name: tags
args.description: (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the Neptune cluster.

args.name: vpc_security_group_ids
args.description: (Optional) List of VPC security groups to associate with the Cluster

args.name: enabled
args.description: (Optional) A boolean flag to enable/disable the subscription. Defaults to true.

args.name: event_categories
args.description: (Optional) A list of event categories for a source_type that you want to subscribe to. Run aws neptune describe-event-categories to find all the event categories.

args.name: name
args.description: (Optional) The name of the Neptune event subscription. By default generated by Terraform.

args.name: name_prefix
args.description: (Optional) The name of the Neptune event subscription. Conflicts with name.

args.name: sns_topic_arn
args.description: (Required) The ARN of the SNS topic to send events to.

args.name: source_ids
args.description: (Optional) A list of identifiers of the event sources for which events will be returned. If not specified, then all sources are included in the response. If specified, a source_type must also be specified.

args.name: source_type
args.description: (Optional) The type of source that will be generating the events. Valid options are db-instance, db-security-group, db-parameter-group, db-snapshot, db-cluster or db-cluster-snapshot. If not set, all sources will be subscribed to.

args.name: tags
args.description: (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the resource.

args.name: id
args.description: The name of the Neptune event notification subscription.

args.name: create
args.description: (Default 40m) How long to wait for creating event subscription to become available.

args.name: delete
args.description: (Default 40m) How long to wait for deleting event subscription to become fully deleted.

args.name: update
args.description: (Default 40m) How long to wait for updating event subscription to complete updates.

args.name: arn
args.description: The Amazon Resource Name of the Neptune event notification subscription.

args.name: customer_aws_id
args.description: The AWS customer account associated with the Neptune event notification subscription.

args.name: cluster_identifier
args.description:
(Required) The Cluster Identifier. Must be a lower case
string.

args.name: database_name
args.description:
(Optional) The name of the first database to be created when the cluster is created.
If you do not provide a name, Amazon Redshift will create a default database called dev.

args.name: node_type
args.description: (Required) The node type to be provisioned for the cluster.

args.name: cluster_type
args.description: (Optional) The cluster type to use. Either single-node or multi-node.

args.name: master_password
args.description:
(Required unless a snapshot_identifier is provided) Password for the master DB user.
  Note that this may show up in logs, and it will be stored in the state file. Password must contain at least 8 chars and
  contain at least one uppercase letter, one lowercase letter, and one number.

args.name: master_username
args.description: (Required unless a snapshot_identifier is provided) Username for the master DB user.

args.name: cluster_security_groups
args.description: (Optional) A list of security groups to be associated with this cluster.

args.name: vpc_security_group_ids
args.description: (Optional) A list of Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) security groups to be associated with the cluster.

args.name: cluster_subnet_group_name
args.description: (Optional) The name of a cluster subnet group to be associated with this cluster. If this parameter is not provided the resulting cluster will be deployed outside virtual private cloud (VPC).

args.name: availability_zone
args.description: (Optional) The EC2 Availability Zone (AZ) in which you want Amazon Redshift to provision the cluster. For example, if you have several EC2 instances running in a specific Availability Zone, then you might want the cluster to be provisioned in the same zone in order to decrease network latency.

args.name: preferred_maintenance_window
args.description: (Optional) The weekly time range (in UTC) during which automated cluster maintenance can occur.                                        Format: ddd:hh24:mi-ddd:hh24:mi

args.name: cluster_parameter_group_name
args.description: (Optional) The name of the parameter group to be associated with this cluster.

args.name: automated_snapshot_retention_period
args.description: (Optional) The number of days that automated snapshots are retained. If the value is 0, automated snapshots are disabled. Even if automated snapshots are disabled, you can still create manual snapshots when you want with create-cluster-snapshot. Default is 1.

args.name: port
args.description: (Optional) The port number on which the cluster accepts incoming connections.                The cluster is accessible only via the JDBC and ODBC connection strings. Part of the connection string requires the port on which the cluster will listen for incoming connections. Default port is 5439.

args.name: cluster_version
args.description: (Optional) The version of the Amazon Redshift engine software that you want to deploy on the cluster.                           The version selected runs on all the nodes in the cluster.

args.name: allow_version_upgrade
args.description: (Optional) If true , major version upgrades can be applied during the maintenance window to the Amazon Redshift engine that is running on the cluster. Default is true

args.name: number_of_nodes
args.description: (Optional) The number of compute nodes in the cluster. This parameter is required when the ClusterType parameter is specified as multi-node. Default is 1.

args.name: publicly_accessible
args.description: (Optional) If true, the cluster can be accessed from a public network. Default is true.

args.name: encrypted
args.description: (Optional) If true , the data in the cluster is encrypted at rest.

args.name: enhanced_vpc_routing
args.description: (Optional) If true , enhanced VPC routing is enabled.

args.name: kms_key_id
args.description: (Optional) The ARN for the KMS encryption key. When specifying kms_key_id, encrypted needs to be set to true.

args.name: elastic_ip
args.description: (Optional) The Elastic IP (EIP) address for the cluster.

args.name: skip_final_snapshot
args.description: (Optional) Determines whether a final snapshot of the cluster is created before Amazon Redshift deletes the cluster. If true , a final cluster snapshot is not created. If false , a final cluster snapshot is created before the cluster is deleted. Default is false.

args.name: final_snapshot_identifier
args.description: (Optional) The identifier of the final snapshot that is to be created immediately before deleting the cluster. If this parameter is provided, skip_final_snapshot must be false.

args.name: snapshot_identifier
args.description: (Optional) The name of the snapshot from which to create the new cluster.

args.name: snapshot_cluster_identifier
args.description: (Optional) The name of the cluster the source snapshot was created from.

args.name: owner_account
args.description: (Optional) The AWS customer account used to create or copy the snapshot. Required if you are restoring a snapshot you do not own, optional if you own the snapshot.

args.name: iam_roles
args.description: (Optional) A list of IAM Role ARNs to associate with the cluster. A Maximum of 10 can be associated to the cluster at any time.

args.name: logging
args.description: (Optional) Logging, documented below.

args.name: enable
args.description: (Required) Enables logging information such as queries and connection attempts, for the specified Amazon Redshift cluster.

args.name: bucket_name
args.description:
(Optional, required when enable_logging is true) The name of an existing S3 bucket where the log files are to be stored. Must be in the same region as the cluster and the cluster must have read bucket and put object permissions.
For more information on the permissions required for the bucket, please read the AWS documentation

args.name: s3_key_prefix
args.description: (Optional) The prefix applied to the log file names.

args.name: snapshot_copy
args.description: (Optional) Configuration of automatic copy of snapshots from one region to another. Documented below.

args.name: destination_region
args.description: (Required) The destination region that you want to copy snapshots to.

args.name: retention_period
args.description: (Optional) The number of days to retain automated snapshots in the destination region after they are copied from the source region. Defaults to 7.

args.name: grant_name
args.description: (Optional) The name of the snapshot copy grant to use when snapshots of an AWS KMS-encrypted cluster are copied to the destination region.

args.name: tags
args.description: (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the resource.

e.g. CMD_LINE, HTML_ENTITY_DECODE or NONE.

for all supported values.

based on the settings in the specified ByteMatchSet, IPSet, SqlInjectionMatchSet, XssMatchSet, or SizeConstraintSet.
For example, if an IPSet includes the IP address 192.0.2.44, AWS WAF will allow or block requests based on that IP address.
If set to true, AWS WAF will allow, block, or count requests based on all IP addresses except 192.0.2.44.

args.name: priority
args.description:
(Required) Specifies the order in which the rules in a WebACL are evaluated.
Rules with a lower value are evaluated before rules with a higher value.

args.name: rule_id
args.description: (Required) ID of the associated WAF (Regional) rule (e.g. aws_wafregional_rule). WAF (Global) rules cannot be used.

args.name: action
args.description: (Optional) Configuration block of the action that CloudFront or AWS WAF takes when a web request matches the conditions in the rule.  Not used if type is GROUP. Detailed below.

args.name: type
args.description: (Required) Specifies how you want AWS WAF Regional to respond to requests that match the settings in a rule. e.g. ALLOW, BLOCK or COUNT

args.name: override_action
args.description: (Optional) Configuration block of the override the action that a group requests CloudFront or AWS WAF takes when a web request matches the conditions in the rule.  Only used if type is GROUP. Detailed below.

args.name: type
args.description: (Optional) The rule type, either REGULAR, as defined by Rule, RATE_BASED, as defined by RateBasedRule, or GROUP, as defined by RuleGroup. The default is REGULAR. If you add a RATE_BASED rule, you need to set type as RATE_BASED. If you add a GROUP rule, you need to set type as GROUP.

args.name: reference_name
args.description:
(Optional) This is a reference name used in Caller Reference
  (helpful for identifying single health_check set amongst others)

args.name: fqdn
args.description: (Optional) The fully qualified domain name of the endpoint to be checked.

args.name: ip_address
args.description: (Optional) The IP address of the endpoint to be checked.

args.name: port
args.description: (Optional) The port of the endpoint to be checked.

args.name: type
args.description: (Required) The protocol to use when performing health checks. Valid values are HTTP, HTTPS, HTTP_STR_MATCH, HTTPS_STR_MATCH, TCP, CALCULATED and CLOUDWATCH_METRIC.

args.name: failure_threshold
args.description: (Required) The number of consecutive health checks that an endpoint must pass or fail.

args.name: request_interval
args.description: (Required) The number of seconds between the time that Amazon Route 53 gets a response from your endpoint and the time that it sends the next health-check request.

args.name: resource_path
args.description: (Optional) The path that you want Amazon Route 53 to request when performing health checks.

args.name: search_string
args.description: (Optional) String searched in the first 5120 bytes of the response body for check to be considered healthy. Only valid with HTTP_STR_MATCH and HTTPS_STR_MATCH.

args.name: measure_latency
args.description: (Optional) A Boolean value that indicates whether you want Route 53 to measure the latency between health checkers in multiple AWS regions and your endpoint and to display CloudWatch latency graphs in the Route 53 console.

args.name: invert_healthcheck
args.description: (Optional) A boolean value that indicates whether the status of health check should be inverted. For example, if a health check is healthy but Inverted is True , then Route 53 considers the health check to be unhealthy.

args.name: enable_sni
args.description: (Optional) A boolean value that indicates whether Route53 should send the fqdn to the endpoint when performing the health check. This defaults to AWS' defaults: when the type is "HTTPS" enable_sni defaults to true, when type is anything else enable_sni defaults to false.

args.name: child_healthchecks
args.description: (Optional) For a specified parent health check, a list of HealthCheckId values for the associated child health checks.

args.name: child_health_threshold
args.description: (Optional) The minimum number of child health checks that must be healthy for Route 53 to consider the parent health check to be healthy. Valid values are integers between 0 and 256, inclusive

args.name: cloudwatch_alarm_name
args.description: (Optional) The name of the CloudWatch alarm.

args.name: cloudwatch_alarm_region
args.description: (Optional) The CloudWatchRegion that the CloudWatch alarm was created in.

args.name: insufficient_data_health_status
args.description: (Optional) The status of the health check when CloudWatch has insufficient data about the state of associated alarm. Valid values are Healthy , Unhealthy and LastKnownStatus.

args.name: regions
args.description: (Optional) A list of AWS regions that you want Amazon Route 53 health checkers to check the specified endpoint from.

args.name: tags
args.description: (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the health check.

args.name: cloudwatch_log_group_arn
args.description: (Required) CloudWatch log group ARN to send query logs.

args.name: zone_id
args.description: (Required) Route53 hosted zone ID to enable query logs.

attrs.name: id
attrs.description: The query logging configuration ID

args.name: zone_id
args.description: (Required) The ID of the hosted zone to contain this record.

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) The name of the record.

args.name: type
args.description: (Required) The record type. Valid values are A, AAAA, CAA, CNAME, MX, NAPTR, NS, PTR, SOA, SPF, SRV and TXT.

args.name: ttl
args.description: (Required for non-alias records) The TTL of the record.

args.name: records
args.description: (Required for non-alias records) A string list of records. To specify a single record value longer than 255 characters such as a TXT record for DKIM, add \"\" inside the Terraform configuration string (e.g. "first255characters\"\"morecharacters").

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) DNS domain name for a CloudFront distribution, S3 bucket, ELB, or another resource record set in this hosted zone.

args.name: zone_id
args.description: (Required) Hosted zone ID for a CloudFront distribution, S3 bucket, ELB, or Route 53 hosted zone. See resource_elb.zone_id for example.

args.name: evaluate_target_health
args.description: (Required) Set to true if you want Route 53 to determine whether to respond to DNS queries using this resource record set by checking the health of the resource record set. Some resources have special requirements, see related part of documentation.

args.name: set_identifier
args.description: (Optional) Unique identifier to differentiate records with routing policies from one another. Required if using failover, geolocation, latency, or weighted routing policies documented below.

args.name: health_check_id
args.description: (Optional) The health check the record should be associated with.

args.name: alias
args.description:
(Optional) An alias block. Conflicts with ttl & records.
Alias record documented below.

args.name: failover_routing_policy
args.description: (Optional) A block indicating the routing behavior when associated health check fails. Conflicts with any other routing policy. Documented below.

args.name: geolocation_routing_policy
args.description: (Optional) A block indicating a routing policy based on the geolocation of the requestor. Conflicts with any other routing policy. Documented below.

args.name: latency_routing_policy
args.description: (Optional) A block indicating a routing policy based on the latency between the requestor and an AWS region. Conflicts with any other routing policy. Documented below.

args.name: weighted_routing_policy
args.description: (Optional) A block indicating a weighted routing policy. Conflicts with any other routing policy. Documented below.

args.name: multivalue_answer_routing_policy
args.description: (Optional) Set to true to indicate a multivalue answer routing policy. Conflicts with any other routing policy.

args.name: allow_overwrite
args.description: (Optional) Allow creation of this record in Terraform to overwrite an existing record, if any. This does not prevent other resources within Terraform or manual Route53 changes from overwriting this record. true by default.

args.name: type
args.description: (Required) PRIMARY or SECONDARY. A PRIMARY record will be served if its healthcheck is passing, otherwise the SECONDARY will be served. See http://docs.aws.amazon.com/Route53/latest/DeveloperGuide/dns-failover-configuring-options.html#dns-failover-failover-rrsets

args.name: continent
args.description: A two-letter continent code. See http://docs.aws.amazon.com/Route53/latest/APIReference/API_GetGeoLocation.html for code details. Either continent or country must be specified.

args.name: country
args.description: A two-character country code or * to indicate a default resource record set.

args.name: subdivision
args.description: (Optional) A subdivision code for a country.

args.name: region
args.description: (Required) An AWS region from which to measure latency. See http://docs.aws.amazon.com/Route53/latest/DeveloperGuide/routing-policy.html#routing-policy-latency

args.name: weight
args.description: (Required) A numeric value indicating the relative weight of the record. See http://docs.aws.amazon.com/Route53/latest/DeveloperGuide/routing-policy.html#routing-policy-weighted.

attrs.name: name
attrs.description: The name of the record.

attrs.name: fqdn
attrs.description: FQDN built using the zone domain and name.

args.name: comment
args.description: (Optional) A comment for the hosted zone. Defaults to 'Managed by Terraform'.

args.name: delegation_set_id
args.description: (Optional) The ID of the reusable delegation set whose NS records you want to assign to the hosted zone. Conflicts with vpc and vpc_id as delegation sets can only be used for public zones.

args.name: force_destroy
args.description: (Optional) Whether to destroy all records (possibly managed outside of Terraform) in the zone when destroying the zone.

args.name: tags

args.name: vpc
args.description: (Optional) Configuration block(s) specifying VPC(s) to associate with a private hosted zone. Conflicts with delegation_set_id, vpc_id, and vpc_region in this resource and any aws_route53_zone_association resource specifying the same zone ID. Detailed below.

args.name: vpc_id
args.description: (Required) ID of the VPC to associate.

args.name: vpc_region
args.description: (Optional) Region of the VPC to associate. Defaults to AWS provider region.

args.name: vpc_id
args.description: (Optional, DEPRECATED) Use vpc instead. The VPC to associate with a private hosted zone. Specifying vpc_id will create a private hosted zone. Conflicts with delegation_set_id as delegation sets can only be used for public zones and vpc.

args.name: vpc_region
args.description: (Optional, DEPRECATED) Use vpc instead. The VPC's region. Defaults to the region of the AWS provider.

attrs.name: zone_id
attrs.description: The Hosted Zone ID. This can be referenced by zone records.

attrs.name: name_servers
attrs.description:
A list of name servers in associated (or default) delegation set.
Find more about delegation sets in AWS docs.

args.name: vpc_id
args.description: (Required) The VPC to associate with the private hosted zone.

args.description: (Optional) The VPC's region. Defaults to the region of the AWS provider.

attrs.name: id

args.name: account_id
args.description: (Optional) AWS account ID to configure. Defaults to automatically determined account ID of the Terraform AWS provider.

args.name: block_public_acls
args.description:
(Optional) Whether Amazon S3 should block public ACLs for buckets in this account. Defaults to false. Enabling this setting does not affect existing policies or ACLs. When set to true causes the following behavior:
PUT Bucket acl and PUT Object acl calls will fail if the specified ACL allows public access.
PUT Object calls will fail if the request includes an object ACL.

args.name: block_public_policy
args.description:
(Optional) Whether Amazon S3 should block public bucket policies for buckets in this account. Defaults to false. Enabling this setting does not affect existing bucket policies. When set to true causes Amazon S3 to:
Reject calls to PUT Bucket policy if the specified bucket policy allows public access.

args.name: ignore_public_acls
args.description:
(Optional) Whether Amazon S3 should ignore public ACLs for buckets in this account. Defaults to false. Enabling this setting does not affect the persistence of any existing ACLs and doesn't prevent new public ACLs from being set. When set to true causes Amazon S3 to:
Ignore all public ACLs on buckets in this account and any objects that they contain.

args.name: restrict_public_buckets
args.description:
(Optional) Whether Amazon S3 should restrict public bucket policies for buckets in this account. Defaults to false. Enabling this setting does not affect previously stored bucket policies, except that public and cross-account access within any public bucket policy, including non-public delegation to specific accounts, is blocked. When set to true:
Only the bucket owner and AWS Services can access buckets with public policies.

args.name: id
args.description: AWS account ID

args.name: bucket
args.description: (Optional, Forces new resource) The name of the bucket. If omitted, Terraform will assign a random, unique name.

args.name: bucket_prefix
args.description: (Optional, Forces new resource) Creates a unique bucket name beginning with the specified prefix. Conflicts with bucket.

args.name: acl
args.description: (Optional) The canned ACL to apply. Defaults to "private".

args.name: policy
args.description: (Optional) A valid bucket policy JSON document. Note that if the policy document is not specific enough (but still valid), Terraform may view the policy as constantly changing in a terraform plan. In this case, please make sure you use the verbose/specific version of the policy. For more information about building AWS IAM policy documents with Terraform, see the AWS IAM Policy Document Guide.

args.name: tags
args.description: (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the bucket.

args.name: prefix
args.description: For a specific rule,  conflicts with filter

args.name: filter
args.description: If any rule has  specified then they all must

args.name: priority
args.description: is optional (with a default value of 0) but must be unique between multiple rules

args.name: force_destroy
args.description: (Optional, Default:false ) A boolean that indicates all objects should be deleted from the bucket so that the bucket can be destroyed without error. These objects are not recoverable.

args.name: website

args.name: index_document
args.description: (Required, unless using redirect_all_requests_to) Amazon S3 returns this index document when requests are made to the root domain or any of the subfolders.

args.name: error_document

args.name: redirect_all_requests_to
args.description: (Optional) A hostname to redirect all website requests for this bucket to. Hostname can optionally be prefixed with a protocol (http:// or https://) to use when redirecting requests. The default is the protocol that is used in the original request.

args.name: routing_rules
args.description:
(Optional) A json array containing routing rules
describing redirect behavior and when redirects are applied.

args.name: cors_rule

args.description: (Optional) Enable versioning. Once you version-enable a bucket, it can never return to an unversioned state. You can, however, suspend versioning on that bucket.

args.name: mfa_delete
args.description: (Optional) Enable MFA delete for either Change the versioning state of your bucket or Permanently delete an object version. Default is false.

args.name: logging
args.description: (Optional) A settings of bucket logging (documented below).

args.name: target_bucket

args.name: target_prefix

args.name: noncurrent_version_transition

args.name: region

args.name: request_payer

(Optional) Specifies who should bear the cost of Amazon S3 data transfer.
Can be either BucketOwner or Requester. By default, the owner of the S3 bucket would incur

developer guide for more information.

args.description: (Required) Indicates whether this bucket has an Object Lock configuration enabled. Valid value is Enabled.

args.name: allowed_headers
args.description: (Optional) Specifies which headers are allowed.

args.name: allowed_origins

args.name: expose_headers

args.name: max_age_seconds

args.name: days

args.name: expired_object_delete_marker
args.description: (Optional) On a versioned bucket (versioningenabled or versioning-suspended bucket), you can add this element in the lifecycle configuration to direct Amazon S3 to delete expired object delete markers.

args.name: date
args.description: (Optional) Specifies the date after which you want the corresponding action to take effect.

args.name: days

args.name: storage_class
args.description: (Required) Specifies the Amazon S3 storage class to which you want the object to transition. Can be ONEZONE_IA, STANDARD_IA, INTELLIGENT_TIERING, or GLACIER.

args.name: days

args.description: (optional) The AWS KMS master key ID used for the SSE-KMS encryption. This can only be used when you set the value of sse_algorithm as aws:kms. The default aws/s3 AWS KMS master key is used if this element is absent while the sse_algorithm is aws:kms.

args.name: priority
args.description: (Optional) The priority associated with the rule.

args.name: destination

args.name: replica_kms_key_id
args.description:
(Optional) Destination KMS encryption key ARN for SSE-KMS replication. Must be used in conjunction with
sse_kms_encrypted_objects source selection criteria.

args.name: access_control_translation
args.description: (Optional) Specifies the overrides to use for object owners on replication. Must be used in conjunction with account_id owner override configuration.

args.name: account_id
args.description: (Optional) The Account ID to use for overriding the object owner on replication. Must be used in conjunction with access_control_translation override configuration.

args.name: source_selection_criteria
args.description: (Optional) Specifies special object selection criteria (documented below).

args.name: sse_kms_encrypted_objects
args.description:
(Optional) Match SSE-KMS encrypted objects (documented below). If specified, replica_kms_key_id
 in destination must be specified as well.

args.name: prefix
args.description: (Optional) Object keyname prefix identifying one or more objects to which the rule applies.

args.name: status
args.description: (Required) The status of the rule. Either Enabled or Disabled. The rule is ignored if status is not Enabled.

args.name: filter
args.description: (Optional) Filter that identifies subset of objects to which the replication rule applies (documented below).

args.name: prefix
args.description: (Optional) Object keyname prefix that identifies subset of objects to which the rule applies.

args.name: tags
args.description:
(Optional)  A mapping of tags that identifies subset of objects to which the rule applies.
The rule applies only to objects having all the tags in its tagset.

args.name: enabled
args.description: (Required) Boolean which indicates if this criteria is enabled.

args.name: apply_server_side_encryption_by_default
args.description: (required) A single object for setting server-side encryption by default. (documented below)

args.name: owner

args.name: default_retention
args.description: (Required) The default retention period that you want to apply to new objects placed in this bucket.

args.description: (Required unless content or content_base64 is set) The path to a file that will be read and uploaded as raw bytes for the object content.

args.name: content
args.description: (Required unless source or content_base64 is set) Literal string value to use as the object content, which will be uploaded as UTF-8-encoded text.

args.name: content_base64
args.description: (Required unless source or content is set) Base64-encoded data that will be decoded and uploaded as raw bytes for the object content. This allows safely uploading non-UTF8 binary data, but is recommended only for small content such as the result of the gzipbase64 function with small text strings. For larger objects, use source to stream the content from a disk file.

args.name: acl
args.description: (Optional) The canned ACL to apply. Defaults to "private".

args.name: cache_control
args.description: (Optional) Specifies caching behavior along the request/reply chain Read w3c cache_control for further details.

args.name: content_disposition
args.description: (Optional) Specifies presentational information for the object. Read w3c content_disposition for further information.

args.name: content_encoding
args.description: (Optional) Specifies what content encodings have been applied to the object and thus what decoding mechanisms must be applied to obtain the media-type referenced by the Content-Type header field. Read w3c content encoding for further information.

args.name: content_language
args.description: (Optional) The language the content is in e.g. en-US or en-GB.

args.name: content_type
args.description: (Optional) A standard MIME type describing the format of the object data, e.g. application/octet-stream. All Valid MIME Types are valid for this input.

args.name: website_redirect
args.description: (Optional) Specifies a target URL for website redirect.

args.name: storage_class
args.description:
(Optional) Specifies the desired Storage Class
for the object. Can be either "STANDARD", "REDUCED_REDUNDANCY", "ONEZONE_IA", "INTELLIGENT_TIERING", "GLACIER", or "STANDARD_IA". Defaults to "STANDARD".

args.name: etag
args.description:
(Optional) Used to trigger updates. The only meaningful value is ${md5(file("path/to/file"))}.
This attribute is not compatible with KMS encryption, kms_key_id or server_side_encryption = "aws:kms".

args.name: server_side_encryption
args.description: (Optional) Specifies server-side encryption of the object in S3. Valid values are "AES256" and "aws:kms".

args.name: kms_key_id
args.description:
(Optional) Specifies the AWS KMS Key ARN to use for object encryption.
This value is a fully qualified ARN of the KMS Key. If using aws_kms_key,
use the exported arn attribute:`kms_key_id = "${aws_kms_key.foo.arn}"`

args.name: tags
args.description: (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the object.

attrs.name: id
attrs.description: the key of the resource supplied above

attrs.name: etag
attrs.description: the ETag generated for the object (an MD5 sum of the object content). For plaintext objects or objects encrypted with an AWS-managed key, the hash is an MD5 digest of the object data. For objects encrypted with a KMS key or objects created by either the Multipart Upload or Part Copy operation, the hash is not an MD5 digest, regardless of the method of encryption. More information on possible values can be found on Common Response Headers.

A unique version ID value for the object, if bucket versioning
is enabled.

args.name: bucket
args.description: (Required) The name of the bucket to which to apply the policy.

args.name: policy
args.description: (Required) The text of the policy. For more information about building AWS IAM policy documents with Terraform, see the AWS IAM Policy Document Guide.

args.name: bucket
args.description: (Required) S3 Bucket to which this Public Access Block configuration should be applied.

args.name: block_public_acls
args.description:
(Optional) Whether Amazon S3 should block public ACLs for this bucket. Defaults to false. Enabling this setting does not affect existing policies or ACLs. When set to true causes the following behavior:
PUT Bucket acl and PUT Object acl calls will fail if the specified ACL allows public access.
PUT Object calls will fail if the request includes an object ACL.

args.name: block_public_policy
args.description:
(Optional) Whether Amazon S3 should block public bucket policies for this bucket. Defaults to false. Enabling this setting does not affect the existing bucket policy. When set to true causes Amazon S3 to:
Reject calls to PUT Bucket policy if the specified bucket policy allows public access.

args.name: ignore_public_acls
args.description:
(Optional) Whether Amazon S3 should ignore public ACLs for this bucket. Defaults to false. Enabling this setting does not affect the persistence of any existing ACLs and doesn't prevent new public ACLs from being set. When set to true causes Amazon S3 to:
Ignore all public ACLs on buckets in this account and any objects that they contain.

args.name: restrict_public_buckets
args.description:
(Optional) Whether Amazon S3 should restrict public bucket policies for this bucket. Defaults to false. Enabling this setting does not affect the previously stored bucket policy, except that public and cross-account access within the public bucket policy, including non-public delegation to specific accounts, is blocked. When set to true:
Only the bucket owner and AWS Services can access this buckets if it has a public policy.

args.name: name
args.description: (Optional) Specifies the friendly name of the new secret. The secret name can consist of uppercase letters, lowercase letters, digits, and any of the following characters: /_+=.@- Conflicts with name_prefix.

args.name: name_prefix
args.description: (Optional) Creates a unique name beginning with the specified prefix. Conflicts with name.

args.description: (Optional) A description of the secret.

args.name: kms_key_id
args.description: (Optional) Specifies the ARN or alias of the AWS KMS customer master key (CMK) to be used to encrypt the secret values in the versions stored in this secret. If you don't specify this value, then Secrets Manager defaults to using the AWS account's default CMK (the one named aws/secretsmanager). If the default KMS CMK with that name doesn't yet exist, then AWS Secrets Manager creates it for you automatically the first time.

args.name: policy
args.description: (Optional) A valid JSON document representing a resource policy. For more information about building AWS IAM policy documents with Terraform, see the AWS IAM Policy Document Guide.

args.name: recovery_window_in_days
args.description: (Optional) Specifies the number of days that AWS Secrets Manager waits before it can delete the secret. This value can be 0 to force deletion without recovery or range from 7 to 30 days. The default value is 30.

args.name: rotation_lambda_arn
args.description: (Optional) Specifies the ARN of the Lambda function that can rotate the secret.

args.name: rotation_rules
args.description: (Optional) A structure that defines the rotation configuration for this secret. Defined below.

args.name: automatically_after_days
args.description: (Required) Specifies the number of days between automatic scheduled rotations of the secret.

args.name: tags
args.description: (Optional) Specifies a key-value map of user-defined tags that are attached to the secret.

args.name: id
args.description: Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the secret.

args.name: arn
args.description: Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the secret.

args.name: rotation_enabled
args.description: Specifies whether automatic rotation is enabled for this secret.

args.name: secret_id
args.description: (Required) Specifies the secret to which you want to add a new version. You can specify either the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) or the friendly name of the secret. The secret must already exist.

args.name: secret_string
args.description: (Optional) Specifies text data that you want to encrypt and store in this version of the secret. This is required if secret_binary is not set.

args.name: secret_binary
args.description: (Optional) Specifies binary data that you want to encrypt and store in this version of the secret. This is required if secret_string is not set. Needs to be encoded to base64.

args.name: version_stages
args.description: (Optional) Specifies a list of staging labels that are attached to this version of the secret. A staging label must be unique to a single version of the secret. If you specify a staging label that's already associated with a different version of the same secret then that staging label is automatically removed from the other version and attached to this version. If you do not specify a value, then AWS Secrets Manager automatically moves the staging label AWSCURRENT to this new version on creation.

args.description: The unique identifier of the version of the secret.

until this is done. See below for an example of how this might be achieved
when the domain is hosted in Route 53 and managed by Terraform.  Find out
more about verifying domains in Amazon SES in the AWS SES
docs.

args.name: routing_policy
args.description: (Optional) The routing policy that you want to apply to all records that Route 53 creates when you register an instance and specify the service. Valid Values: MULTIVALUE, WEIGHTED

args.name: ttl
args.description: (Required) The amount of time, in seconds, that you want DNS resolvers to cache the settings for this resource record set.

args.name: type
args.description: (Required, ForceNew) The type of the resource, which indicates the value that Amazon Route 53 returns in response to DNS queries. Valid Values: A, AAAA, SRV, CNAME

args.name: failure_threshold
args.description: (Optional) The number of consecutive health checks. Maximum value of 10.

args.name: resource_path
args.description: (Optional) The path that you want Route 53 to request when performing health checks. Route 53 automatically adds the DNS name for the service. If you don't specify a value, the default value is /.

args.name: type
args.description: (Optional, ForceNew) The type of health check that you want to create, which indicates how Route 53 determines whether an endpoint is healthy. Valid Values: HTTP, HTTPS, TCP

args.name: failure_threshold
args.description: (Optional, ForceNew) The number of 30-second intervals that you want service discovery to wait before it changes the health status of a service instance.  Maximum value of 10.

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) The friendly name for the SNS platform application

args.name: platform
args.description: (Required) The platform that the app is registered with. See Platform for supported platforms.

args.name: platform_credential
args.description: (Required) Application Platform credential. See Credential for type of credential required for platform. The value of this attribute when stored into the Terraform state is only a hash of the real value, so therefore it is not practical to use this as an attribute for other resources.

args.name: event_delivery_failure_topic_arn
args.description: (Optional) SNS Topic triggered when a delivery to any of the platform endpoints associated with your platform application encounters a permanent failure.

args.name: event_endpoint_created_topic_arn
args.description: (Optional) SNS Topic triggered when a new platform endpoint is added to your platform application.

args.name: event_endpoint_deleted_topic_arn
args.description: (Optional) SNS Topic triggered when an existing platform endpoint is deleted from your platform application.

args.name: event_endpoint_updated_topic_arn
args.description: (Optional) SNS Topic triggered when an existing platform endpoint is changed from your platform application.

args.name: failure_feedback_role_arn
args.description: (Optional) The IAM role permitted to receive failure feedback for this application.

args.name: platform_principal
args.description: (Optional) Application Platform principal. See Principal for type of principal required for platform. The value of this attribute when stored into the Terraform state is only a hash of the real value, so therefore it is not practical to use this as an attribute for other resources.

args.name: success_feedback_role_arn
args.description: (Optional) The IAM role permitted to receive success feedback for this application.

args.name: success_feedback_sample_rate
args.description: (Optional) The percentage of success to sample (0-100)

args.name: monthly_spend_limit
args.description: (Optional) The maximum amount in USD that you are willing to spend each month to send SMS messages.

args.name: delivery_status_iam_role_arn
args.description: (Optional) The ARN of the IAM role that allows Amazon SNS to write logs about SMS deliveries in CloudWatch Logs.

args.name: delivery_status_success_sampling_rate
args.description: (Optional) The percentage of successful SMS deliveries for which Amazon SNS will write logs in CloudWatch Logs. The value must be between 0 and 100.

args.name: default_sender_id
args.description: (Optional) A string, such as your business brand, that is displayed as the sender on the receiving device.

args.name: default_sms_type
args.description: (Optional) The type of SMS message that you will send by default. Possible values are: Promotional, Transactional

args.name: usage_report_s3_bucket
args.description: (Optional) The name of the Amazon S3 bucket to receive daily SMS usage reports from Amazon SNS.

attrs.name: id
attrs.description: The ARN of the SNS topic

attrs.name: arn
attrs.description: The ARN of the SNS topic, as a more obvious property (clone of id)

args.name: arn
args.description: (Required) The ARN of the SNS topic

args.name: policy
args.description: (Required) The fully-formed AWS policy as JSON. For more information about building AWS IAM policy documents with Terraform, see the AWS IAM Policy Document Guide.

args.name: topic_arn
args.description: (Required) The ARN of the SNS topic to subscribe to

args.name: protocol
args.description: (Required) The protocol to use. The possible values for this are: sqs, sms, lambda, application. (http or https are partially supported, see below) (email is option but unsupported, see below).

args.name: lambda
args.description: - delivery of JSON-encoded message to a lambda function

args.name: sqs
args.description: - delivery of JSON-encoded message to an Amazon SQS queue

args.name: application
args.description: - delivery of JSON-encoded message to an EndpointArn for a mobile app and device

args.name: sms
args.description: - delivery text message

args.name: http
args.description: - delivery of JSON-encoded messages via HTTP. Supported only for the end points that auto confirms the subscription.

args.name: https
args.description: - delivery of JSON-encoded messages via HTTPS. Supported only for the end points that auto confirms the subscription.

args.name: email
args.description: - delivery of message via SMTP

args.name: endpoint
args.description: (Required) The endpoint to send data to, the contents will vary with the protocol. (see below for more information)

args.name: endpoint_auto_confirms
args.description: (Optional) Boolean indicating whether the end point is capable of auto confirming subscription e.g., PagerDuty (default is false)

args.name: confirmation_timeout_in_minutes
args.description: (Optional) Integer indicating number of minutes to wait in retying mode for fetching subscription arn before marking it as failure. Only applicable for http and https protocols (default is 1 minute).

args.name: raw_message_delivery
args.description: (Optional) Boolean indicating whether or not to enable raw message delivery (the original message is directly passed, not wrapped in JSON with the original message in the message property) (default is false).

args.name: filter_policy
args.description: (Optional) JSON String with the filter policy that will be used in the subscription to filter messages seen by the target resource. Refer to the SNS docs for more details.

args.name: delivery_policy
args.description: (Optional) JSON String with the delivery policy (retries, backoff, etc.) that will be used in the subscription - this only applies to HTTP/S subscriptions. Refer to the SNS docs for more details.

attrs.name: id
attrs.description: The ARN of the subscription

attrs.name: topic_arn
attrs.description: The ARN of the topic the subscription belongs to

attrs.name: protocol
attrs.description: The protocol being used

attrs.name: endpoint
attrs.description: The full endpoint to send data to (SQS ARN, HTTP(S) URL, Application ARN, SMS number, etc.)

attrs.name: arn
attrs.description: The ARN of the subscription stored as a more user-friendly property

args.description: (Optional) The default name of the registered managed instance.

args.name: description
args.description: (Optional) The description of the resource that you want to register.

args.name: expiration_date
args.description: (Optional) A timestamp in RFC3339 format by which this activation request should expire. The default value is 24 hours from resource creation time.

args.name: iam_role

args.name: registration_limit
args.description: (Optional) The maximum number of managed instances you want to register. The default value is 1 instance.

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) The name of the SSM document to apply.

args.name: association_name
args.description: (Optional) The descriptive name for the association.

args.name: document_version
args.description: (Optional) The document version you want to associate with the target(s). Can be a specific version or the default version.

args.name: instance_id
args.description: (Optional) The instance ID to apply an SSM document to. Use targets with key InstanceIds for document schema versions 2.0 and above.

args.name: key
args.description: (Required) Either InstanceIds or tag:Tag Name to specify an EC2 tag.

args.name: values
args.description: (Required) A list of instance IDs or tag values. AWS currently limits this to 1 target value.

args.name: output_location
args.description: (Optional) An output location block. Output Location is documented below.

args.name: s3_bucket_name
args.description: (Required) The S3 bucket name.

args.name: s3_key_prefix
args.description: (Optional) The S3 bucket prefix. Results stored in the root if not configured.

args.name: parameters
args.description: (Optional) A block of arbitrary string parameters to pass to the SSM document.

args.name: schedule_expression
args.description: (Optional) A cron expression when the association will be applied to the target(s).

args.name: targets
args.description: (Optional) A block containing the targets of the SSM association. Targets are documented below. AWS currently supports a maximum of 5 targets.

attrs.name: name
attrs.description: The name of the SSM document to apply.

attrs.name: instance_ids
attrs.description: The instance id that the SSM document was applied to.

attrs.name: parameters

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) The name of the document.

args.name: content
args.description: (Required) The JSON or YAML content of the document.

args.name: document_format
args.description: (Optional, defaults to JSON) The format of the document. Valid document types include: JSON and YAML

args.name: document_type
args.description: (Required) The type of the document. Valid document types include: Command, Policy, Automation and Session

args.name: permissions
args.description: (Optional) Additional Permissions to attach to the document. See Permissions below for details.

args.name: tags
args.description: (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the object.

attrs.name: schema_version

attrs.name: default_version
attrs.description: The default version of the document.

attrs.name: hash
attrs.description: The sha1 or sha256 of the document content

attrs.name: hash_type
attrs.description: "Sha1" "Sha256". The hashing algorithm used when hashing the content.

attrs.name: latest_version
attrs.description: The latest version of the document.

attrs.name: owner
attrs.description: The AWS user account of the person who created the document.

attrs.name: status
attrs.description: "Creating", "Active" or "Deleting". The current status of the document.

attrs.name: parameter

attrs.name: platform_types

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) The name of the maintenance window.

args.name: schedule
args.description: (Required) The schedule of the Maintenance Window in the form of a cron or rate expression.

args.name: cutoff
args.description: (Required) The number of hours before the end of the Maintenance Window that Systems Manager stops scheduling new tasks for execution.

args.name: duration
args.description: (Required) The duration of the Maintenance Window in hours.

args.name: allow_unassociated_targets
args.description: (Optional) Whether targets must be registered with the Maintenance Window before tasks can be defined for those targets.

args.name: enabled
args.description: (Optional) Whether the maintenance window is enabled. Default: true.

args.name: end_date
args.description: (Optional) Timestamp in ISO-8601 extended format when to no longer run the maintenance window.

args.name: schedule_timezone
args.description: (Optional) Timezone for schedule in Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA) Time Zone Database format. For example: America/Los_Angeles, etc/UTC, or Asia/Seoul.

args.name: start_date
args.description: (Optional) Timestamp in ISO-8601 extended format when to begin the maintenance window.

attrs.name: id
attrs.description: The ID of the maintenance window.

args.name: window_id
args.description: (Required) The Id of the maintenance window to register the target with.

args.name: resource_type
args.description: (Required) The type of target being registered with the Maintenance Window. Possible values INSTANCE.

args.name: targets
args.description: (Required) The targets (either instances or tags). Instances are specified using Key=instanceids,Values=instanceid1,instanceid2. Tags are specified using Key=tag name,Values=tag value.

args.name: owner_information
args.description: (Optional) User-provided value that will be included in any CloudWatch events raised while running tasks for these targets in this Maintenance Window.

attrs.name: id
attrs.description: The ID of the maintenance window target.

args.name: window_id
args.description: (Required) The Id of the maintenance window to register the task with.

args.name: max_concurrency
args.description: (Required) The maximum number of targets this task can be run for in parallel.

args.name: max_errors
args.description: (Required) The maximum number of errors allowed before this task stops being scheduled.

args.name: task_type
args.description: (Required) The type of task being registered. The only allowed value is RUN_COMMAND.

args.name: task_arn
args.description: (Required) The ARN of the task to execute.

args.name: service_role_arn
args.description: (Required) The role that should be assumed when executing the task.

args.name: name
args.description: (Optional) The name of the maintenance window task.

args.name: description
args.description: (Optional) The description of the maintenance window task.

args.name: targets
args.description: (Required) The targets (either instances or window target ids). Instances are specified using Key=InstanceIds,Values=instanceid1,instanceid2. Window target ids are specified using Key=WindowTargetIds,Values=window target id1, window target id2.

args.name: priority
args.description: (Optional) The priority of the task in the Maintenance Window, the lower the number the higher the priority. Tasks in a Maintenance Window are scheduled in priority order with tasks that have the same priority scheduled in parallel.

args.name: logging_info
args.description: (Optional) A structure containing information about an Amazon S3 bucket to write instance-level logs to. Documented below.

args.name: s3_bucket_name
args.description: (Required)

args.name: s3_region
args.description: (Required)

args.name: s3_bucket_prefix
args.description: (Optional)

args.name: task_parameters
args.description: (Optional) A structure containing information about parameters required by the particular task_arn. Documented below.

args.name: name
args.description: (Required)

args.name: values
args.description: (Required)

attrs.name: id
attrs.description: The ID of the maintenance window task.

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) The name of the patch baseline.

args.name: description
args.description: (Optional) The description of the patch baseline.

args.name: operating_system
args.description: (Optional) Defines the operating system the patch baseline applies to. Supported operating systems include WINDOWS, AMAZON_LINUX, AMAZON_LINUX_2, SUSE, UBUNTU, CENTOS, and REDHAT_ENTERPRISE_LINUX. The Default value is WINDOWS.

args.name: approved_patches_compliance_level
args.description: (Optional) Defines the compliance level for approved patches. This means that if an approved patch is reported as missing, this is the severity of the compliance violation. Valid compliance levels include the following: CRITICAL, HIGH, MEDIUM, LOW, INFORMATIONAL, UNSPECIFIED. The default value is UNSPECIFIED.

args.name: approved_patches
args.description: (Optional) A list of explicitly approved patches for the baseline.

args.name: rejected_patches
args.description: (Optional) A list of rejected patches.

args.name: global_filter
args.description: (Optional) A set of global filters used to exclude patches from the baseline. Up to 4 global filters can be specified using Key/Value pairs. Valid Keys are PRODUCT | CLASSIFICATION | MSRC_SEVERITY | PATCH_ID.

args.name: approval_rule
args.description: (Optional) A set of rules used to include patches in the baseline. up to 10 approval rules can be specified. Each approval_rule block requires the fields documented below.

args.name: approve_after_days
args.description: (Required) The number of days after the release date of each patch matched by the rule the patch is marked as approved in the patch baseline. Valid Range: 0 to 100.

args.name: patch_filter
args.description: (Required) The patch filter group that defines the criteria for the rule. Up to 4 patch filters can be specified per approval rule using Key/Value pairs. Valid Keys are PRODUCT | CLASSIFICATION | MSRC_SEVERITY | PATCH_ID.

args.name: compliance_level
args.description: (Optional) Defines the compliance level for patches approved by this rule. Valid compliance levels include the following: CRITICAL, HIGH, MEDIUM, LOW, INFORMATIONAL, UNSPECIFIED. The default value is UNSPECIFIED.

args.name: enable_non_security
args.description: (Optional) Boolean enabling the application of non-security updates. The default value is 'false'. Valid for Linux instances only.

attrs.name: id
attrs.description: The ID of the patch baseline.

args.name: baseline_id
args.description: (Required) The ID of the patch baseline to register the patch group with.

args.name: patch_group
args.description: (Required) The name of the patch group that should be registered with the patch baseline.

attrs.name: id
attrs.description: The ID of the patch baseline.

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) The name of the parameter. If the name contains a path (e.g. any forward slashes (/)), it must be fully qualified with a leading forward slash (/). For additional requirements and constraints, see the AWS SSM User Guide.

args.name: type
args.description: (Required) The type of the parameter. Valid types are String, StringList and SecureString.

args.name: value
args.description: (Required) The value of the parameter.

args.name: description
args.description: (Optional) The description of the parameter.

args.name: key_id
args.description: (Optional) The KMS key id or arn for encrypting a SecureString.

args.name: overwrite
args.description: (Optional) Overwrite an existing parameter. If not specified, will default to false if the resource has not been created by terraform to avoid overwrite of existing resource and will default to true otherwise (terraform lifecycle rules should then be used to manage the update behavior).

args.name: allowed_pattern
args.description: (Optional) A regular expression used to validate the parameter value.

args.name: tags
args.description: (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the object.

attrs.name: arn
attrs.description: The ARN of the parameter.

attrs.name: name

attrs.name: description

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) Name for the configuration.

args.name: s3_destination
args.description: (Required) Amazon S3 configuration details for the sync.

args.name: bucket_name
args.description: (Required) Name of S3 bucket where the aggregated data is stored.

args.name: region
args.description: (Required) Region with the bucket targeted by the Resource Data Sync.

args.name: kms_key_arn
args.description: (Optional) ARN of an encryption key for a destination in Amazon S3.

args.name: prefix
args.description: (Optional) Prefix for the bucket.

args.name: sync_format
args.description: (Optional) A supported sync format. Only JsonSerDe is currently supported. Defaults to JsonSerDe.

args.name: name
args.description: (Optional) This is the human-readable name of the queue. If omitted, Terraform will assign a random name.

args.name: name_prefix
args.description: (Optional) Creates a unique name beginning with the specified prefix. Conflicts with name.

args.name: visibility_timeout_seconds
args.description: (Optional) The visibility timeout for the queue. An integer from 0 to 43200 (12 hours). The default for this attribute is 30. For more information about visibility timeout, see AWS docs.

args.name: message_retention_seconds
args.description: (Optional) The number of seconds Amazon SQS retains a message. Integer representing seconds, from 60 (1 minute) to 1209600 (14 days). The default for this attribute is 345600 (4 days).

args.name: max_message_size
args.description: (Optional) The limit of how many bytes a message can contain before Amazon SQS rejects it. An integer from 1024 bytes (1 KiB) up to 262144 bytes (256 KiB). The default for this attribute is 262144 (256 KiB).

args.name: delay_seconds
args.description: (Optional) The time in seconds that the delivery of all messages in the queue will be delayed. An integer from 0 to 900 (15 minutes). The default for this attribute is 0 seconds.

args.name: receive_wait_time_seconds
args.description: (Optional) The time for which a ReceiveMessage call will wait for a message to arrive (long polling) before returning. An integer from 0 to 20 (seconds). The default for this attribute is 0, meaning that the call will return immediately.

args.name: policy
args.description: (Optional) The JSON policy for the SQS queue. For more information about building AWS IAM policy documents with Terraform, see the AWS IAM Policy Document Guide.

args.name: redrive_policy
args.description: (Optional) The JSON policy to set up the Dead Letter Queue, see AWS docs. Note: when specifying maxReceiveCount, you must specify it as an integer (5), and not a string ("5").

args.name: fifo_queue
args.description: (Optional) Boolean designating a FIFO queue. If not set, it defaults to false making it standard.

args.name: content_based_deduplication
args.description: (Optional) Enables content-based deduplication for FIFO queues. For more information, see the related documentation

args.name: kms_master_key_id
args.description: (Optional) The ID of an AWS-managed customer master key (CMK) for Amazon SQS or a custom CMK. For more information, see Key Terms.

args.name: kms_data_key_reuse_period_seconds
args.description: (Optional) The length of time, in seconds, for which Amazon SQS can reuse a data key to encrypt or decrypt messages before calling AWS KMS again. An integer representing seconds, between 60 seconds (1 minute) and 86,400 seconds (24 hours). The default is 300 (5 minutes).

args.name: tags
args.description: (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the queue.

attrs.name: id
attrs.description: The URL for the created Amazon SQS queue.

attrs.name: arn
attrs.description: The ARN of the SQS queue

args.name: queue_url
args.description: (Required) The URL of the SQS Queue to which to attach the policy

args.name: policy
args.description: (Required) The JSON policy for the SQS queue. For more information about building AWS IAM policy documents with Terraform, see the AWS IAM Policy Document Guide.

args.name: disk_id
args.description: (Required) Local disk identifier. For example, pci-0000:03:00.0-scsi-0:0:0:0.

args.name: gateway_arn
args.description: (Required) The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the gateway.

args.name: id
args.description: Combined gateway Amazon Resource Name (ARN) and local disk identifier.

args.name: gateway_arn
args.description: (Required) The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the gateway.

args.name: network_interface_id
args.description: (Required) The network interface of the gateway on which to expose the iSCSI target. Only IPv4 addresses are accepted.

args.name: target_name
args.description: (Required) The name of the iSCSI target used by initiators to connect to the target and as a suffix for the target ARN. The target name must be unique across all volumes of a gateway.

args.name: volume_size_in_bytes
args.description: (Required) The size of the volume in bytes.

args.name: snapshot_id
args.description: (Optional) The snapshot ID of the snapshot to restore as the new cached volume. e.g. snap-1122aabb.

args.name: source_volume_arn
args.description: (Optional) The ARN for an existing volume. Specifying this ARN makes the new volume into an exact copy of the specified existing volume's latest recovery point. The volume_size_in_bytes value for this new volume must be equal to or larger than the size of the existing volume, in bytes.

args.name: arn
args.description: Volume Amazon Resource Name (ARN), e.g. arn:aws:storagegateway:us-east-1:123456789012:gateway/sgw-12345678/volume/vol-12345678.

args.name: chap_enabled
args.description: Whether mutual CHAP is enabled for the iSCSI target.

args.name: id
args.description: Volume Amazon Resource Name (ARN), e.g. arn:aws:storagegateway:us-east-1:123456789012:gateway/sgw-12345678/volume/vol-12345678.

args.name: lun_number
args.description: Logical disk number.

args.name: network_interface_port
args.description: The port used to communicate with iSCSI targets.

args.name: target_arn
args.description: Target Amazon Resource Name (ARN), e.g. arn:aws:storagegateway:us-east-1:123456789012:gateway/sgw-12345678/target/iqn.1997-05.com.amazon:TargetName.

args.name: volume_arn
args.description: Volume Amazon Resource Name (ARN), e.g. arn:aws:storagegateway:us-east-1:123456789012:gateway/sgw-12345678/volume/vol-12345678.

args.name: volume_id
args.description: Volume ID, e.g. vol-12345678.

args.name: gateway_name
args.description: (Required) Name of the gateway.

args.name: gateway_timezone
args.description: (Required) Time zone for the gateway. The time zone is of the format "GMT", "GMT-hr:mm", or "GMT+hr:mm". For example, GMT-4:00 indicates the time is 4 hours behind GMT. The time zone is used, for example, for scheduling snapshots and your gateway's maintenance schedule.

args.name: activation_key
args.description: (Optional) Gateway activation key during resource creation. Conflicts with gateway_ip_address. Additional information is available in the Storage Gateway User Guide.

args.name: gateway_ip_address
args.description: (Optional) Gateway IP address to retrieve activation key during resource creation. Conflicts with activation_key. Gateway must be accessible on port 80 from where Terraform is running. Additional information is available in the Storage Gateway User Guide.

args.name: gateway_type
args.description: (Optional) Type of the gateway. The default value is STORED. Valid values: CACHED, FILE_S3, STORED, VTL.

args.name: media_changer_type
args.description: (Optional) Type of medium changer to use for tape gateway. Terraform cannot detect drift of this argument. Valid values: STK-L700, AWS-Gateway-VTL.

args.name: smb_active_directory_settings
args.description: (Optional) Nested argument with Active Directory domain join information for Server Message Block (SMB) file shares. Only valid for FILE_S3 gateway type. Must be set before creating ActiveDirectory authentication SMB file shares. More details below.

args.name: smb_guest_password
args.description: (Optional) Guest password for Server Message Block (SMB) file shares. Only valid for FILE_S3 gateway type. Must be set before creating GuestAccess authentication SMB file shares. Terraform can only detect drift of the existence of a guest password, not its actual value from the gateway. Terraform can however update the password with changing the argument.

args.name: tape_drive_type
args.description: (Optional) Type of tape drive to use for tape gateway. Terraform cannot detect drift of this argument. Valid values: IBM-ULT3580-TD5.

args.name: domain_name
args.description: (Required) The name of the domain that you want the gateway to join.

args.name: password
args.description: (Required) The password of the user who has permission to add the gateway to the Active Directory domain.

args.name: username
args.description: (Required) The user name of user who has permission to add the gateway to the Active Directory domain.

args.name: id
args.description: Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the gateway.

args.name: create
args.description: (Default 10m) How long to wait for gateway activation and connection to Storage Gateway.
